poem:
Title: A Stitch in Time's Fabric

In the fields of Sunderland South,
Labour's loom did spin,
Warp and weft of political truth, 
hush-hush in the wind.

In the folds of hallowed halls,
official whispers shared,
A dance of power, a regional call,
yet a national dare.

Through the mist of machinations,
Order shines, and cracks the crust,
A story sewn in the fabric of the nation,
In the end, truth we trust.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I’ve seen Labour stitch-ups in my time. But nothing as shameless as this | Chris Mullin There is nothing new about Labour officials rigging parliamentary selections. In 1985, when I applied for Sunderland South, Labour’s north-east regional organiser instructed the local party not to circulate the details of applicants from outside the region. Happily, when the party’s national organiser heard about this, she summoned him and ordered him to rescind his instruction. Whereupon the old". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
